@Fiskantes Basically

But if commodities are the best framework for thinking through these native assets, then many blockchains will likely need to undergo tokeneconomic revamps to better calibrate these assets to accrue value (tweaking supply emissions, adding burning mechanisms, etc)

The native assets of smart contract platforms may ultimately be valued this way as well. 

ETH has long been dubbed digital oil for years now for this reason (oil is a much larger market than gold btw).

The exceptions to this model would blockchains whose native asset‚Äôs primary use is neither as a currency or fee payment asset, but more like a commodity (i.e use asset to access resources blockchain is providing).

Helium‚Äôs HNT is a good example of this.

Building a currency is an unnecessary undertaking for most blockchains (inclusive of L1s, L2s, app-chain, etc).

Many would be better off having their validators accept fees paid in external assets which have more credibility and reliability as currencies (BTC, ETH, stablecoins).

The idea of L1s accruing value from fee generation is convoluted by the circular logic of them generating fees in currencies they issue.

The only economic frameworks that make sense for understanding the native assets of L1s are that of commodities or currencies.

BTC is what you get when you invent groundbreaking new technology but overfit it to an archaic idea of money (gold).

ETH is what you get when you invent groundbreaking new technology and shatter the idea of money by creating the base asset of an economy from first principles.

It‚Äôs not much different than any other country vying for reserve currency status.

Grow your own economic influence, then get other countries to use your currency to buy the goods and services of and invest in  your economy.

But in the long term, it seems the path with less resistance to reach monetary supremacy is to grow the cryptoeconomy until its GDP is the largest in the world.

The insight is it‚Äôs easier to compete in parallel with countries rather than head on trying to usurp their currencies.

In the short - med term it‚Äôs probably easier to compete with gold than grow your digital economy to a size where it‚Äôs anywhere close to that of a dominant nation state.

Bitcoin is undeniably the leader here - less counterparty risk, more liquid, and more stable (technically).

‚Ä¶Ethereum needs to compete with fiat currencies on its own home turf ü§î

Already today ETH has lost its status as the dominant currency on Ethereum to the dollar.

The ultimate question is how this trends over the coming years.

The latter path - build your own digital economy until the economic might of it surpasses those of the dominant sovereign powers, is a path with less resistance, but is a FAR more ambitious undertaking.

Ethereum is well on its way there with its robust and booming economy, but‚Ä¶

And as mentioned before demand for outside money (money that is not anyone‚Äôs liability) like BTC and Gold is set to explode.

So thesis for this path, succinctly, is win market share from gold in a growing pie for apolitical SoVs. https://t.co/6qpv1y5pag

This is important because money is a network and if Bitcoin has challenges bootstrapping a commercial network, it‚Äôs utility (and value) may ultimately be limited.

That said, there‚Äôs a ton of value in just narrowly being a SoV asset like gold - which is worth over $12 trillion‚Ä¶

But Bitcoin‚Äôs use as a MoE is challenged.

There‚Äôs no compelling case to use BTC in IRL commerce given its volatility and scaling limitations.

Not to mention sovereigns will be reluctant to cede control over their monetary systems and lose a precious economic management tool.

The former is difficult if you‚Äôre competing with fiat currencies head on, but promising if you‚Äôre challenging gold.

Yes, the case for apolitical SoVs continues to grow with monetary and financial deplatforming rising (ex: Russia and Canada), and an increasingly multipolar world.

The way I see it, cryptocurrencies have two paths to reach reserve currency status.

Either challenge nation states head-on for monetary supremacy like Bitcoin, or grow your own digital economy until it surpasses those of the dominant sovereign powers like Ethereum.

So what does this mean?

Web 3 gaming currencies are subject to market forces not even remotely comparable to Web 2 games. 

Their job to hold and accrue real value is far more difficult, and much more akin to building a currency for a new country in the real world.

Web 3 gaming economies are far different. 

1) Free floating currencies

2) Free capital flow

3) Free exchange - users can transact among each other, with the publisher, and engage in either side of a transaction (buying or selling).

It‚Äôs a free market and open economy.

Combined you have a system where capital flows in at a fixed exchange rate, accrues solely to the publisher, and can never leave the system.

It‚Äôs a closed economy where the publisher effectively just issues you a stablecoin you can never redeem and can only use on their platform
3) Users can only transact with the game publisher (and only in one way - user buys from publisher).

The reason why in game currencies work easily in Web 2 is that:

1) All the virtual currencies are convertible at a fixed price to the dollar (fixed exchange rate).

2) Capital can only flow into the economy (capital controls).
In game currencies aren‚Äôt a dead end, but what you must understand is that building a self sustaining economy is difficult.

If I had to guess why it would be that many of the founders in these sectors are new to the industry and aren‚Äôt aware of the lessons we‚Äôve learned since 2017 (i.e the velocity problem).

The Compound community has much to look forward to in the coming quarters with the impending launch of Compound Chain, the key pillar of Compound‚Äôs multichain strategy, as well as Compound Treasury, a key enabler of institutional adoption.

As with most financial services businesses, Compound protocol will always exhibit some degree of cyclicality as it continues to grow and be adopted. The past nine months in 2021 were a testament to that.

In summary. 

Although Q3 got off to a slow start in depths of the summer slow down, growth returned in the back half of the quarter driving many metrics to all-time high levels.

Compound Governance was also busy in Q3, with over 11 proposals passing in the quarter, and 4 new markets added.

Below is a timeline of the events. https://t.co/ZvuqaMijvD

Finally, one of the key drivers of all this activity and ultimately what jump started growth in Compound markets back in June of 2020, COMP token incentives, also were lower this quarter. 

This was driven by lower COMP prices following the May crash. https://t.co/wbtxxlfpya

Unsurprisingly, liquidations decreased substantially in the quarter, following Q2‚Äôs extreme market volatility.

Considering market volatility in the 1st half of Q3 was relatively muted, with the 2nd half of Q3 being fairly one-directional (up), its unsurprising liquidations fell. https://t.co/Vqb0ePLHgl

This largely reflected lower interest rates charged on DAI and USDC loans for most of the quarter.

Similarly, due to lower borrowing rates, protocol income (reserve factor) saw its first down quarter in over a year falling 17% from $11 million to $9 million. https://t.co/XeRLIbnkfz

Historically low interest rates also caused Compound to have its first quarter in over a year with lower interest income than the prior quarter. 

Despite loans growing 57% in the quarter, interest income declined 19% from $96 million in Q2 to $78 million in Q3. https://t.co/LeAIycX6i7

This trend of depositor growth outpacing loan growth is perhaps best captured by Compound‚Äôs aggregate utilization ratio. 

Since the beginning of 2021 utilization fell 20% from from 58% to 38% as depositors flooded Compound markets with liquidity. https://t.co/ChusjHLZEx

Depositors are now receiving the least amount of interest they‚Äôve received in Compound‚Äôs history as Compound markets liquidity builds. 

Although the story is nuanced across individual markets, with stablecoin yields having picked up materially in Q3 after reaching lows in July. https://t.co/e1sExgGT8J

Outstanding deposits grew 48% in Q3, driven by rising token prices, as well as fresh deposits chasing higher yields as activity picked up. 

WETH, USDC, and DAI contributed most to growth in Q3. https://t.co/jbn9fTrAdr

Between rising collateral values, more favorable market conditions, and attractive borrowing costs, borrowers returned in droves in Q3. 

Unsurprisingly, most of this borrowing activity was denominated in USDC and DAI. https://t.co/ahytr44OJM

Outstanding loans grew 57% in Q3.

A key driver of this growth was the increase in Compound markets liquidity since Q1, which drove interest rates down to their lowest levels in history. 

However as utilization increased in USDC and DAI markets, rates began rising by Q3 end. https://t.co/SZ2LQYtsl7

Insights from Macro below.

After seeing metrics fall across the board following the May market crash and subsequent slow down, activity picked up substantially as we reached the end of Q3 2021. 

By the end of the quarter Compound reached new all-time highs across most KPIs. https://t.co/NghHjTk184

Below are a few of my favorite resources that helped inform this thread as well as my thoughts overall on stablecoins.

Especially disruptive when we continue to observe the trend of decentralized stablecoins continue to win share, which may not be able to be shutdown or restricted by regulators.

üëÄ

So in summary stablecoins are big deal and there‚Äôs a reason why regulators are watching the space so closely. 

They‚Äôre incredibley disruptive on a global scale and there‚Äôs tens of trillions of dollars at stake if not more.

While the size of the offshore dollar market (dollar deposits held outside the US) is difficult to estimate, data from the BIS suggests it could be over $57 trillion dollars. 

It may sound crazy, but this is the market stablecoins are beginning to eat into. https://t.co/o5KvNrbE08

The offshore case.

Stablecoins could service offshore dollar demand by providing individuals and institutions around the world with easy access to dollars due to stablecoins being natively digital, globally accessible, and more seizure resistant.

The domestic case stablecoins.

Over time financial institutions shift more transactions to blockchains due to:

1. Properties explained above (24/7, programmable, cheap, reliable, etc).

2. Fundamentally leaner cost structure from shifting capex (infrastructure) to blockchains.

With the US dollar accounting for about 55% of the world‚Äôs international transactions, savings, and borrowing, there is large structural global demand for USD, especially outside the US financial system.

Stablecoins are one of the few applications of public blockchains that legitimately have a multi-trillion dollar addressable market. 

Why? 

It‚Äôs all about the US Dollar. https://t.co/LFL9L6xQ7B

So where could we be going with all this?

The shaky regulatory environment complicates the story, but here‚Äôs how big it could potentially get.
In short, stablecoins are simply a better means of storing and moving dollars around the world.

- They offer users stronger autonomy, privacy, and interoperability than existing payments solutions which require KYC and often restrict access

- They‚Äôre programmable which allows for developers to trivially build with them and deploy applications with global distribution

Why do stablecoins continue to find product market fit?

- They‚Äôre easy to accept as payments given that all you need is an address on a public blockchain

- They run on global public infrastructure that operates 24/7/365 which makes them available, cheap, and reliable to use

People use stablecoins so much that in Q2 users transacted over $1.7 trillion on blockchains using stablecoins. 

That was up 14x in the past year. https://t.co/R4Cv8yixyQ

Stablecoins have found a variety of uses within the industry including as:

- currency to move value between exchanges

- collateral for use on derivatives exchanges

- medium of exchange and store of value in DeFi

- currency for cross border payments

The stablecoin supply reached $120 billion this week.

Why do stablecoins continue to grow so fast and just how big could this get?

Ethereum may continue to be the dominant platform with everyone else playing catch up. 

It may continue to be the home base for all grassroots innovation. 

It may continue to be the home of DeFi and NFTs.

It may continue to win the hearts and minds of the crypto community‚Ä¶

Not only is there a chance that one competitor may unseat Ethereum for the number one spot, but there may also be room for more than one at the top.

It may not even be a war after all.
If that is indeed where we‚Äôre headed, then there‚Äôs an incredible amount of opportunity among Ethereum‚Äôs competitors and provides even more reason why the sector attracts so much speculation.

Perhaps this model applies to blockchains as well. 

Blockchains are becoming more composable and many offer functionality not available on other chains due to design trade-offs. 

We may ultimately find these chains create more value together than they can individually.

A cryptoeconomy with multiple winners wouldn‚Äôt be dissimilar to the world we live in today, with five dominant $1+ trillion technology companies (Apple, Amazon, Microsoft, Google, Facebook).

None of these investors are complaining either.

Another key piece of the valuation puzzle revolves around how the ultimate market for smart contract platforms shapes up.

In other words how will the multi-trillion $$ pie be split?

One chain to rule them all or multiple winners?

Generalization or specialization?

Could Ethereum‚Äôs competitors replicate this growth in the next 18 months? 

Could they even grow faster? 

This is the bet smart contract speculators are making and being rewarded for.

If Ethereum is any guide, fundamentals can change very fast. 

18 months ago Ethereum had barely any meaningful activity. 

Today it secures $700 billion in assets, settles $2.5 trillion a quarter, and host thousands of applications.

So how does this apply to smart contract platforms?

Speculators aren‚Äôt valuing competitors to Ethereum based on their fundamentals at this snapshot in time, they‚Äôre valuing their fundamentals as they may look in the future.

Willingness to pay also involves quantitative and qualitative factors. 

It determines how much an investor is willing to pay now for those fundamentals ‚ÄúX‚Äù number of years in the future. 

This is influenced by relative valuation, macro conditions, narratives, memes, and more.

Fundamentals involve quantitative factors like TVL and transaction volume, in addition to qualitative factors like competitiveness and developer interest. 

Markets are forward looking, and what drives valuations are what these fundamentals may look like tomorrow, not today.

Let‚Äôs return to the basics of valuation.

At the most basic level two things drive valuations: fundamentals and willingness to pay (h/t @HighCoinviction).

The interpretation of (lack of) usage however is wrong and here‚Äôs why. 

Markets are forward looking, not backward looking.

The observation about usage is not incorrect. 

Compared to Ethereum most smart contract platforms have little activity.

Sure we know at the extremes what‚Äôs decentralized and what‚Äôs not. But the middle is where most legitimate blockchains sit and we have no idea how to objectively measure their decentralization. 

Makes discussion about these topics very difficult and often just opinionated.

Do we use the Nakamoto Coefficient?

Node count?

Node requirements?

Token distribution?

Developer count?

Client diversity?

There‚Äôs no clear answer. It‚Äôs a mosaic pieced together from many different things with no objective thresholds of what‚Äôs decentralized enough or not.

The biggest challenge with blockchain decentralization arguments is not just that we don‚Äôt yet know what enough decentralization is, but that we don‚Äôt even have standards for measuring decentralization in the first place.

How are avg users suppose to know if we don‚Äôt even know?

Wrote about these ideas a few months ago in @MessariCrypto newsletter, but figure it needed an update after more thought on the topic. https://t.co/EOXh1YCXY7
If this scenario plays out then Ethereum may end up capturing more value from DeFi than DeFi protocols themselves (not even including ETH‚Äôs monetary premium) https://t.co/cYZIy4425A

On one hand lower margins for DeFi protocols means more surplus to users, both on the supply and demand side (DeFi protocols are marketplaces).

But it also means Ethereum captures a higher % of total fees per transaction as gas becomes a larger portion relative to protocol fees.

Anyways, so where does ETH fit in?

Well think about what value capture looks like if DeFi protocols have low pricing power.

Some protocols may also be able to capture more value depending on design decisions.

Ex: MakerDAO‚Äôs cost of capital is zero due to it creating its own lending inventory, allowing it to capture more value than secondary market lenders which most source inventory and pay for it.

On the other hand there are legit ways DeFi protocols can build sustainable competitive advantages that may allow them to achieve greater pricing power than what appears on the surface. 

Wrote about this in depth here.

https://t.co/KL9ke2syg8

On one hand open source development and permissionless protocols lead to low switching costs (competitors can copy your code and users can leave in an instant) so it's possible protocols will have low pricing power over users.

Pricing Power - How much can DeFi protocols charge users for their services? 

This is the least certain variable of the three, but may be the most important in determining the terminal value of DeFi protocols. https://t.co/LtSzlSpSW5

What this means is entire sectors of the financial services industry worth trillions of $$$ being replaced by just 1-2 protocols per sector. 

That is an incredible market opportunity.

The most likely scenario to me is each vertical having 1-2 dominant protocols. 

If every protocol is permissionless to use and build upon why not just use whichever protocols are best of breed? 

Bundling doesn‚Äôt seem a likely winning strategy.

Market Structure - Will DeFi be a ‚Äúwinner-take-all / most‚Äù market?

In any case, decentralized stablecoins, led my DAI, continue to be one of if not the most important building blocks in DeFi to get right long-term.
The most interesting of this batch aim to eliminate dollar dependency altogether.

There‚Äôs still no decentralized stablecoin project that‚Äôs come close to the success of MakerDAO, but there‚Äôs a ton exploring the design space of decentralized stablecoins in search of alternative solutions.

DAI‚Äôs progress towards this is promising, but even still only has ~8% market share.

Ironically it‚Äôs also becoming increasingly reliant on USDC via its peg stabilization module. https://t.co/lWZxkIhzcX

The question from here on out is how much DeFi will continue to rely on centralized stablecoins as it continues to grow.

Centralized stablecoins have always been a nice gateway for bringing liquidity into DeFi and avoiding the volatility problem, but never the long-term solution

While this will certainly dilute yields for depositors it will be incredibly valuable in driving adoption of DeFi lending protocols which have historically faced a shortage of dollar liquidity (primary reason rates have been so high).

With the pending launch of Compound Treasury and a swath of initiatives centered around Circle‚Äôs DeFi API it is very likely this trend will continue meaning more dollar liquidity will funnel into DeFi.

Unsurprisingly lending protocols MakerDAO, Compound, and Aave are the largest consumers of USDC, holding ~23% of the USDC supply.

USDC in MakerDAO is primarily used to support the DAI peg via the Peg Stabilization Module.

USDC in Compound and Aave is deposited to earn yield. https://t.co/tJAKfGgpVn

Over 50% of the USDC supply now sit in smart contracts - equivalent to ~$12.5 billion. 

Although this percentage is not as high as DAI, USDC leads by a wide margin in dollar terms and has become the preferred stablecoin in DeFi for now. https://t.co/zKxGPXIzJo

In coming weeks it is very likely USDT‚Äôs share of the stablecoin supply on Ethereum will fall below 50% for the first time.

USDC is quickly emerging as the dominant stablecoin on Ethereum in large part due to its growing role in DeFi.

Perhaps pure play decentralized custodian protocols have some tricks up their sleeves that I‚Äòm not seeing, so I won‚Äôt write them off as not working, but that‚Äôs just how I see the game today.
So in short, cross-chain liquidity protocols are not only a superset of decentralized custodian protocols, but potentially may offer the only scalable way to do decentralized custody.

Cross-chain liquidity protocols like @THORChain have taken this path to decentralized custody by pairing custody with exchange, lending, and synthetic assets.

The idea is that the combination of those will provide sufficient returns to incentivize nodes to stake enough capital.
It is likely that doing the same may offer the only scalable model for decentralized custody under the constraints of the high capital requirements needed.

Even without the overcollaterallization requirements, centralized custodians recognize the unattractiveness of their business.

This leads them to enter new and adjacent markets and is why we see custody in crypto often paired with businesses such as exchange and staking.
We can turn to the centralized custodians once again for insight.

The model doesn‚Äôt scale easily, it‚Äôs just too capital inefficient.

You can‚Äôt just expect the staking token to be worth enough without requisite yield.

So with this in mind overcollateralized decentralized custodians face a serious challenge.

How can they attract enough capital when realistically they‚Äôre only returning <1% to nodes per year into perpetuity?

The difference however is that clients of traditional custodians can rely on a legal system to keep their assets secure.

So we don‚Äôt need BNY Mellon to have $37 trillion at stake to properly secure their $37 trillion in assets under custody. That would be ridiculous.

As mentioned previously the economics of custody are poor. 

Coinbase for example only receives 50bps annualized for custodying assets.

For traditional finance custodians like Bank of New York Mellon it‚Äôs more than an order of magnitude lower.

The above is why many of these protocols such as Ren and Keep have overcollateralizion requirements - it‚Äôs necessary for security in an environment where you can‚Äôt rely on trust.

The issue boils down to incentivizing those nodes to put up enough stake to secure assets custodied.

Fundamentally nodes securing pegged assets must have more at stake than the assets they‚Äôre custodying. 

So if nodes custody $1 billion they must have more at stake than $1 billion otherwise they‚Äôd just steal the assets they‚Äôre custodying.

I‚Äôm increasingly skeptical of the economic viability of pegged asset protocols. 

The issue is that decentralized custody - a requirement for such protocols - is an inherently low margin business and won‚Äôt provide enough returns to nodes to sufficiently incentivize security.

These THORChain vaults provide the foundation for what it calls ‚ÄúTHOFi‚Äù - the aforementioned suite of financial services enabled by THORChain‚Äôs liquidity pools.

At its core THORChain is a vault manager. 

It observes incoming user deposits to vaults, executes business logic (swap, add/remove liquidity), and processes outbound transactions.

The second graphic attached here is an example of a BTC to ETH swap. https://t.co/NBFeGOOYWS

The incentive pendulum is a mechanism that dynamically allocates system income (trading fees and RUNE rewards) between nodes and liquidity providers.

It aims to ensure nodes always are bonding two times more than the value of external assets (non-RUNE) in its liquidity pools. https://t.co/mQFqa0tnog

With each liquidity pool also being half RUNE the network is designed to incentivize a balance of $3 of RUNE for every $1 of external assets in the network. 

It ensures this ratio through the use of a mechanism called the incentive pendulum. https://t.co/O5DEnTh5l1

2. THORChain nodes must bond RUNE in order to become active.

These nodes process transactions and guarantee security for all assets stored in its liquidity pools.

THORChain is secure so long as the RUNE bonded by nodes is >2x the value of external assets in liquidity pools.

1. All assets in THORChain‚Äôs liquidity pools are paired with RUNE, which is the settlement asset of the network.

This allows THORChain to aggregate liquidity more efficiently and prevent liquidity from fragmenting across pools. https://t.co/4sJeHT2t7v
At the core of THORChain is its native token RUNE which plays an essential role in both liquidity provisioning and network security.

THORChain currently supports 5 blockchains including:

- Bitcoin
- Ethereum
- Litecoin
- Bitcoin Cash
- Binance Chain

Traction though limited by its self-imposed caps has been promising, with liquidity pools quickly hitting their new limits each time they are raised. https://t.co/P170Zr1X0E

At a high level THORChain is a network of nodes and liquidity providers.

It recently launched Mainnet in April with caps on liquidity pools.

The community progressively raises these caps as the network proves out its security and works through bugs. https://t.co/YsX3uehIfn

This isn‚Äôt some stupid scheme to destroy our environment.

There are now dozens of Proof of Stake blockchains in existence.

And while newer, the security model continues to become more proven with time.

Proof of Stake promises to increase Ethereum‚Äôs security, energy efficiency, and reduce its centralization risk from miners.

It also aims to ensure participation in the consensus process remains as maximally democratic and open as possible.

Proof of Stake eliminates the mining process and instead replaces it with a new consensus mechanism based on validators economic stakes in the network.

Ethereum is the largest project shifting to this consensus mechanism in the coming months. 

https://t.co/OGDmAHcWkD

All this said, of course if we could achieve a similar outcome without the extreme energy demands that would be desirable.

This is part of why many people in crypto are excited by a newer and increasingly popular way of securing blockchains called Proof of Stake.
With the above in mind, it seems pretty clear to me that there‚Äôs value in a peaceful decentralized money that is open to everyone in the world.

2. How much does Bitcoin really cost when properly compared to other monetary assets such as fiat currencies which require entire armies to run? 

Just look at government spending for the answer.

There‚Äôs two pushbacks I have here.

1. What is the value of a fixed supply digital commodity money that cannot be seized, censored, or corrupted and can be trivially verified and transferred around the world in seconds? 

What if everyone in the world had access to this asset?

This criticism is often birthed from the belief that what Bitcoin mining goes towards isn‚Äôt valuable.

‚ÄúIf Bitcoin is a useless technology, then why are we burning all this energy?‚Äù

While many people cite that 76% of Bitcoin miners use renewable energy, that‚Äôs not entirely correct.

Yes 76% of miners use renewables as part of their energy mix, but only 39% of mining comes from renewable sources.

In any case however this criticism still misses the point.

Be careful of trading decentralized finance on Ethereum for deception finance on Binance Smart Chain. 

Labels and reality are two different things.

You can make money on the way up... BSC will likely have a place in this industry for the foreseeable future. 

But if you really think BSC has achieve smart contract supremacy, and will become the world‚Äôs settlement layer, you are on crack.

Every cycle people get hoodwinked by the latest centralized solution to all blockchains problems.

Every cycle influencers pump these narratives so they can dump on na√Øve retail traders when it‚Äôs over.

That said if you really want speed and scalability outside Ethereum without sharding state and without going entirely centralized, there are more legitimate ways of getting that such as with Solana.

But BSC ain‚Äôt it.

What Binance has done well with BSC is GTM.

Binance has incredible reach and influence and has used that to funnel a boatload of new users in DeFi.

Binance executes period. That‚Äôs why BSC is winning.

The reason why BSC is faster and more scalable is not because of some magical technological innovation. 

No, it‚Äôs instead the magic of centralization. 

BSC is an Ethereum fork with a centralized validator set.

That‚Äôs it. Nothing more.

Price action will cause people to believe anything.

I don‚Äôt care how high BNB or CAKE go, it won‚Äôt change that they‚Äôre still copycats.

It‚Äôs one thing to view these assets as a way to make money, it‚Äôs another to view them as innovations that push this industry forward.

PCV is an exciting new design space that will play a critical role in the next stage of decentralized stablecoins.

Highly recommend checking out our two latest deep dives on the topic to learn more.

https://t.co/CpP4T08Gmn

Ex: Imagine if Fei added a bonding curve for $SUSHI. 

It could use the $SUSHI it accrued through the bonding curve to participate in SushiSwap governance and influence votes.

It‚Äôs also entirely possible that Fei could stake and gain protocol fees as well ü§Ø

But even still that‚Äôs just scratching the surface.

Eventually Fei Protocol may add new bonding curves with governance tokens instead of ETH, potentially allow it to enter the game of meta-governance.

Still, market operations are only scratching the surface of what protocols may do with PCV.

$FRAX for example also uses its PCV to earn yield in other DeFi protocols like Compound, Aave, and Yearn. 

$OHM will soon also deposit its PCV into Rari Capital. https://t.co/8nhMisQQbO

In its Genesis offering Fei raised a warchest $1.3 billion.

Upon close of the offering it deployed its capital to Uniswap and instantly became the largest Uniswap LP by far!

Fei Protocol is now the single largest liquidity provider on Ethereum. https://t.co/sK4lVBhRvo

In extreme scenarios where FEI is below its peg for an extended period of time, the protocol can use its PCV to buy back FEI and burn FEI from the market. 

Fei calls this ‚Äúreweighting‚Äù and it does this through the following trade: https://t.co/0t8r5EOAZ7

Fei Protocol uses its PCV that it raised through its Genesis offering to provide $FEI liquidity on Uniswap. 

This is powerful considering that Fei not only earns fees from $FEI trading, but also gains the ability to manage its own liquidity and strongly influence $FEI‚Äôs price.
Now let‚Äôs use Fei Protocol to highlight how PCV works.

What $FEI, $OHM, $FLOAT, and $FRAX use their PCV for is market operations.

Just like how central banks use their balance sheets to regulate money supplies, these protocols operate similarly.

In fact any protocol that owns external assets (not their own token) in their treasury has PCV.

The difference is how that PCV is used and how it applies to decentralized stablecoins specifically.

The idea of PCV isn‚Äôt exactly novel either. 

It‚Äôs not much different than a protocol owned treasury or insurance fund.

FEI Genesis participants just found this out the hard way.

The ETH they deposited into Fei's bonding curve is not redeemable.

They can only get their ETH back by selling FEI to the protocol on the protocol's terms (currently at a massive discount).
 
https://t.co/JtPwiod8tX

PCV is a fairly simple idea.

It basically just means a protocol itself taking ownership of the collateral it receives when users mint new stablecoins.

This means collateral is not redeemable like it is in MakerDAO.

PCV is a powerful concept that‚Äôs core to of many of the latest decentralized stablecoins including $FEI, $OHM, $FLOAT, and $FRAX.

But what is it and why does it matter?

Non pegged stablecoins may seem like a far-out experiment without a clear use case now. 

But they may also be the best bet this industry has on creating non-sovereign stable cryptocurrencies.

Now entering, the Avant-Garde of decentralized stablecoins. https://t.co/CAHJt5FEPK

Once upon a time we wanted independent currencies for a decentralized financial system. 

Instead we got dollars on a blockchain.

But how do these non pegged stablecoins work really? 

Will they even work, let alone be adopted?

In our second of two reports on central banking on blockchains we dive deep into $RAI, $FLOAT, and $OHM and peek into the future of money on Ethereum.

https://t.co/HvguTRDJjw

Once Ethereum has independent stable currencies, a truly independent banking system can emerge on Ethereum. 

Non pegged stablecoins can be put to work in DeFi money markets and yield aggregators which effectively turn those non pegged stablecoins into banking deposits. https://t.co/5nx5MxQetC

At the core of non pegged stablecoins is collateral, primarily ETH, that ultimately backs their value.

$RAI, $FLOAT, and $OHM each have different mechanisms to stabilize themselves, target prices, and ways of using their collateral.

But that‚Äôs the common thread.

So what does an independent Ethereum monetary system look like? 

In many ways similar to the dollar under the gold standard with a free banking system.

(h/t @Fiskantes)
https://t.co/Sis8WXxrpM

Furthermore the dollar peg also introduces regulatory risk that has the potential to shake the foundations of DeFi. 

Playing with the dollar invites the US government to take action.

Look no further than the STABLE act for indication on what worse case scenario could look like.

In practice stablecoin protocols are more like currency boards than central banks. 

All their monetary policy decisions are subordinated to maintaining their fixed exchange rate targets with the dollar. https://t.co/8xt3d5ZV4P

The flipside of dollarization is that by welcoming stablecoins into its economy, Ethereum has given up its monetary sovereignty and opened itself up to external dependencies that introduce systemic risk.

The stability dollar-pegged stablecoins have brought has enabled Ethereum to attract more capital into its economy as well as boost economic growth. 

Stablecoins have been a key enabler of Ethereum‚Äôs booming DeFi ecosystem.

But it‚Äôs come with trade-offs.

It's not surprising that Ethereum has dollarized. 

Many developing economies dollarize due to monetary instability. 

Stablecoins allow Ethereum to overcome ETH‚Äôs volatility, which would otherwise handicap economic growth. https://t.co/ja6KgsBHSs

This is the idea at the heart of the latest wave of decentralized stablecoins.

These novel projects offer a radical opportunity for Ethereum‚Äôs monetary system to achieve stability while eliminating dependence on fiat currencies.
https://t.co/HvguTRDJjw

Ethereum is an emerging digital economy in the early stages of a multi-decade economic boom.

The Problem?

Dollar-pegged stablecoins dominate Ethereum and the dollar is controlled by the Federal Reserve...

But what if we had stablecoins not pegged to fiat currencies at all?

So where does this algorithmic stablecoin Renaissance, powered by the idea of protocol owned collateral come in?

On the other hand we have decentralized stablecoins which while have also shown great progress are not perfect either.

They‚Äôre often capital inefficient, governance heavy, difficult to scale, and in some cases unstable (like the first generation algorithmic stablecoins).

The leading stablecoins by market capitalization today are centralized (e.g. USDT) and expose their holders to censorship, seizure, and counterparty risk.

The above properties make these stablecoins less socially scalable and less reliable.
But while stablecoins have seen great adoption within crypto so far, and are powerful in their current state, they‚Äôre far from perfect.

While the size of the offshore dollar market (dollars deposits held outside the US) is difficult to estimate, data from the BIS suggests it could be over $57 trillion dollars.

It may sound crazy, but this is the market stablecoins are beginning to eat into. https://t.co/4xCM0eXzv0

Stablecoins are uniquely positioned to service this offshore dollar demand by providing individuals and businesses globally with easy access to dollars due to stablecoins being natively digital, globally accessible, and relatively more seizure resistant.

In our latest piece we provide a brief overview of @thorchain_org's token economics to drive home how tokens can be designed to balance growth, value capture, and sustainability.

https://t.co/XJArPcM8tT

So what is an example of a well designed token that is designed from the ground up to be an integral part of the protocol and involved in the value creation process, rather than just serving to extract rent?
In exchange for ensuring a path to value capture at a surface level, protocols dismissed key features of building lasting technology organizations: sustainability and growth.

As a result we've seen a correction in the opposite direction towards tokens with direct value capture mechanisms.

The problem with this is that in some cases tokens exist to purely extract rent, which is not only not sustainable, but also inhibits growth.

This is for a good reason.

Due to a combination of opportunism and naivete, the 2017 ICO era was flush with utility tokens that attempted to jam useless tokens into new projects.

Over the past year in DeFi there‚Äôs been a renewed interest among the community in value accrual mechanisms for tokens.

https://t.co/XJArPcM8tT

What is the holy grail of token design?

To me it is when a protocol is designed from the ground up so that its token is an integral part of the protocol and involved in the value creation process, rather than just serving to extract rent.

This industry‚Äôs obsession with dividends is a backlash to the useless utility tokens from 2017.

Yes it‚Äôs important for tokens to have the potential to accrue value.

UNI implicitly does this by not extracting fees from LPs (fee switch off).

To me this is the biggest invalidation of the thesis that fee capture today actually matters.

So long as DeFi protocols have 100x+ growth ahead of them:

Growth > Fee Capture.

Dive deeper into the theory of the Yearn to understand what the hell is going on üëáüèæ
https://t.co/qcMMJLlyRp
Yearn‚Äôs recent ‚Äúmergers‚Äù are aimed at creating an ecosystem around Yearn to ensure Yearn becomes the schelling point for capital providers and capital allocators to coordinate around.
At this point, Yearn would become the ‚Äúshelling protocol‚Äù for capital allocation - everyone will coordinate around Yearn, and the incentives to defect to another protocol would be weak.

The greater the capital efficiency in DeFi, the greater the opportunity for Yearn to scale its operations.

The name of the game for Yearn is to attract enough capital and enough capital allocators (strategists) to build a network effect.

What does this all mean?

In short while Yearn, the protocol, is a coordination mechanism for efficient capital allocation, Yearn, the ecosystem, aims to be a conglomerate of symbiotic financial protocols that increase the capital efficiency of DeFi as a whole.

Yearn‚Äôs other mergers are aimed at achieving similar goals of scaling Yearn, whether it be insuring vaults (Cover), attracting institutional liquidity (Akropolis), acquiring strategists (Pickle), or building out an in-house money market (Cream).
Increased capital efficiency is good for Yearn because it boosts the returns for its capital providers (vault depositors).

For example, Yearn‚Äôs plan to launch Deriswap on SushiSwap, has the potential to allow liquidity supplied to SushiSwap to be simultaneously used to facilitate trading, lending, options, and futures, increasing the yield per dollar of liquidity provided.
Instead Yearn is merging developer talent across these protocols to more tightly coordinate roadmaps - an important part of scaling Yearn.

Yearn‚Äôs recent mergers aren‚Äôt mergers in the traditional sense of acquiring assets and governance rights. 

There will still be separate tokens, treasuries, and governance systems for these ‚Äúmerged‚Äù protocols.

But where exactly is Yearn going? 

Yearn‚Äôs recent ‚Äúmergers‚Äù with Pickle, Cream, SushiSwap, Akropolis, and Cover help illuminate Yearn‚Äôs masterplan. https://t.co/E3RH9OcGb4

Yearn is a protocol for capital allocation. 

It coordinates capital allocation through incentivizing capital providers with the highest possible yields, while incentivizing capital allocators (i.e. ‚Äústrategists‚Äù) with the highest possible AUM to allocate.

This protocol would just be a coordinator between capital allocators and capital providers.

And it would provide easy access to and automated management for every financial opportunity available on Ethereum (or any blockchain for that matter).

This is what Yearn is at its core.

Instead it would be a globally accessible, fully transparent, minimally extractive, and credibly neutral protocol that would provide the majority of value created back to users. 

https://t.co/kF5lnYidNp
Nor would it look like a modern wealth management app that is also extractive, beholden to local regulators and limited in its functionality.

It would not look like a plain vanilla savings bank where people deposit their money to a firm, which then uses that money to generate a return - the bank's shareholders reaping the lump sum of the value created.

But the challenge with this freedom is that finance can oftentimes be very complex and with so many opportunities it may be hard for people to decide what to do.

Thus CVP is included in YETI not to ‚Äúride the Yearn merger hype wave,‚Äù rather its included because it economically aligns PowerPool with the underlying protocols in YETI.

https://t.co/IJPdT7eUtn
Having CVP in each index, ensures that index holders have a voice in PowerPool governance and ensures that PowerPool will only be successful if it does its job well.

In short, meta-governance for each PowerPool index is not just a feature of PowerPool indices, it‚Äôs at the core of what PowerPool indices do. 

This is why it presented itself as the best solution to use to launch YETI.
This dynamic also provides the ancillary benefit of scaling Index liquidity mining rewards with total value locked (TVL increases --> higher CVP price --> higher CVP rewards).

These CVP price movements will occur deterministically based on the TVL in the pool because CVP must account for a fixed percentage of the pool.

This dynamic provides strong incentives for CVP holders to do what's best for the composite protocols of each index.

If CVP holders do their job poorly (making clearly bad decisions for index composite protocols), users will withdraw their governance tokens from the index, decreasing total value locked in PowerIndex and negatively influencing CVP token price.
If CVP holders do their job well, more users will supply their governance tokens to the index, increasing the total value locked in PowerIndex and positively influencing the CVP token price.

For example, based on the initial weightings for PIPT, CVP must make up 12.5% of the total value locked in the PowerIndex pool.

What this does is create skin in the game for CVP holders to ensure they are aligned with the governance of underlying DeFi tokens in PowerIndex. https://t.co/aZ0W3C9uaq
The second and perhaps more important reason why CVP is included in each index is to align incentives between PowerPool and the underlying tokens (protocols) in its indices.
PowerPool‚Äôs governance system was designed so that users providing liquidity can simultaneously use their CVP to participate in governance. https://t.co/512RR9DIbH

Index token holders will be able to vote on all proposals and collect rewards using this CVP locked in the index.

For example each PIPT (PowerPool‚Äôs first index) holder's voting power will be a function of their share of the 12.5% of CVP in the PowerIndex pool.

CVP is included in each PowerPool index for two reasons.

The first is to enable index holders to participate in PowerPool governance.

Each index holder's voting power will be a function of their share of CVP locked in the index.

https://t.co/IJPdT7eUtn

Check out our full ETH 2.0 report here to learn more about Ethereum‚Äôs monetary policy and more and find an answer for yourself: https://t.co/vCqxyAA2TU https://t.co/V2TFW4co40

But if it is the case that Ethereum becomes more scarce than Bitcoin, and it‚Äôs security model is more sustainable, both due to PoS, then what will that imply for ETH‚Äôs monetary properties vs Bitcoin‚Äôs?

It will be exciting to see the consequences of each‚Äôs approach to monetary policy and how it will affect their properties as money.

Is security more important or is ‚Äúmonetary perfection‚Äù important?

It‚Äôs to be determined.

But the two approaches to monetary policy have their trade offs. 

Ethereum‚Äôs monetary policy can be hard to quantify and communicate.

While Bitcoin‚Äôs monetary policy sets its security budget arbitrarily.

Ethereum‚Äôs monetary policy is optimized for security.

This is in opposition to Bitcoin‚Äôs monetary policy which optimizes for ‚Äúmonetary perfection‚Äù (fixed supply and deterministic issuance schedule).

The benefit is that Bitcoin‚Äôs monetary policy is ùó∫ùòÇùó∞ùóµ easier to communicate

Ethereum‚Äôs monetary policy can be defined as ‚ÄúMinimum Necessary Issuance‚Äù - the minimum amount of issuance necessary to ensure Ethereum remains secure. 

Although this may seem subjective, like any protocol parameter Ethereum‚Äôs monetary policy is enforced through social consensus

Many may still look at the above insurance schedule and be skeptical.

‚ÄúEthereum‚Äôs monetary policy seems too fluid and unstable‚Äù

And they‚Äôd be somewhat correct in that Ethereum‚Äôs monetary policy is not rigid.

But they‚Äôd also be missing what Ethereum‚Äôs monetary policy truly is.

But Phase 1.5 is anywhere from 12-24  months out.

In the meantime, Ethereum‚Äôs annual issuance rate will actually increase because ETH 2 issuance will be incremental to ETH1.x before the merge.

Important to note though that this incremental issuance is both temporary minimal. https://t.co/EHqnmZft8S
Combine this lower issuance with transaction fee burns (EIP 1559) and there‚Äôs the potential for Ethereum‚Äôs annual issuance rate to drop negative - all while still staying secure.
In other words PoS allows Ethereum to achieve an equal amount of security while issuing significantly less ETH.

Higher capital costs are good because that increases the cost to attack Ethereum.

And the benefit of this is that Ethereum can get an equal amount of security for less dollar rewards (ETH issuance).

One of the core value propositions of PoS is that stakers are theoretically more willing to pay significantly higher capital costs per a dollar of rewards.

This is because they only face an opportunity cost on their investment and don‚Äôt experience any depreciation (like ASICs).

If you‚Äôre an Ethereum skeptic you‚Äôre probably thinking ‚Äúhow is this possible?‚Äù

It all starts with Ethereum‚Äôs shift to Proof of Stake (PoS).

Ethereum often gets criticized for its ‚Äúloose‚Äù monetary policy.

However after Phase 1.5 (ETH 1.x merge into ETH 2), it is likely ETH‚Äôs annual inflation rate will drop well below 1% if not ùóªùó≤ùó¥ùóÆùòÅùó∂ùòÉùó≤.

At this point ETH‚Äôs inflation rate would be far lower than BTC‚Äôs.

The takeaway for investors?

ETH does not fit into a neatly defined bucket.

It is a complete re-imagination of what money is in a blockchain-based economy.

The best way to understand ETH is just to look at it from first principles and appreciate its various drivers of value.

Why do all these properties matter?

They all are sources of demand for ETH in ETH 2.0.

It may not be a stretch to say there‚Äôs never quite been an asset like ETH.

Taking the above into consideration @MaraSchmiedt and @StakeETH conceptualized ETH as:

‚ÄúThe Internet Bond [which is] an entirely new asset for financial markets. It allows anyone in the world to invest, participate, and profit off an open-sourced, decentralized digital economy.‚Äù

Similarly ETH‚Äôs claim on transaction fees makes ETH act more like equity in that it has a claim on future fees from users demanding to transact on Ethereum.

EIP 1559 will likely burn the majority of transaction fees, but some variable portion of fees will be paid to stakers.
Unlike bonds which have maturity dates at which time bond holders are paid back their principal, stakers can stake their ETH and receive yield forever.

However, Ethereum‚Äôs bond-like characteristics are only half the picture. 

Two key features that make ETH equity-like as well are its perpetual nature and its claim on Ethereum‚Äôs transaction fees.

Like sovereign bonds that are issued in a sovereigns own currency, there is no default risk (nominally) with an Ethereum bond.

Ethereum can guarantee to pay out stakers so long as the Ethereum blockchain remains alive
because it pays stakers in its own currency.

...and the reason why Ethereum issues this ‚Äúbond‚Äù in the first place is to raise capital for security. 

The relationship can be analogized to a nation state that issues bonds to pay for its defense budget and in return pays bond holders additional currency that it creates. https://t.co/cf3rkHb4Jg

ETH 2.0 introduces staking which will provide ETH with capital asset properties - it will be used to generate income through staking.

Annual yields stakers can expect to get at maturity will likely be in the 4-6% range. 

Currently they‚Äôre around 20%. https://t.co/OphrfqlRhY

In ETH 1.x ETH possesses commodity properties through its use as ‚Äúdigital oil‚Äù, being used to pay for block space. 

This analogy to oil will be especially powerful once EIP-1559 is implemented and the majority of tx fees are burned - literally converting ETH into block space.

Let‚Äôs start with ETH‚Äôs properties in ETH 1.x.

In ETH 1.x ETH possesses store of value properties through its use as collateral in DeFi and use as Ethereum‚Äôs native currency.

ETH 2.0 transforms Ethereum the blockchain, but what about ETH the asset?

In ETH 1.x ETH is used as a money and commodity.

In ETH 2.0 ETH will also be used to produce income through staking.  

The combination of the 3 will make ETH one of the most unique assets in crypto.

The purpose of all the above principles is to increase Ethereum‚Äôs scalability, security, and energy efficiency without compromising on accessibility or decentralization.

Full Light-Client Verifiability - Many users will only interact with Ethereum through light clients.

Thus it‚Äôs important for those users to be able to verify that the data in the full system is available and valid, even under a 51% attack (under certain assumptions).

And in the case where harmful collusion does take place, it‚Äôs important to make it extremely expensive for those colluding and easy for non-colluding participants to recover the system.

These are the core reasons underlying Ethereum‚Äôs shift to Proof of Stake.

Defense in Depth - Blockchains must work well under a variety of possible security assumptions. 

A key way to achieve this is to design the system so that it is as decentralized as possible to prevent faults, collusions, and attacks. https://t.co/WU2PzEtEN3

Sufficiency - Blockchains must be powerful enough for it to be possible to build trust minimized layer2 protocols on top of it.

In order to achieve this blockchains must include an expressive programming language, scalable data availability and computation, and fast block times.

Long-Term Stability - Although Ethereum so far has favored evolution over stability, ETH 2.0 is designed with the idea that once built, there should be little need to change it for long periods of time - a necessity for Ethereum to serve as public infrastructure.

With this in mind ETH 2.0 was designed with five key principles: 

- Simplicity
- Long-term stability
- Sufficiency
- Defense in depth
- Full light-client verifiability

https://t.co/QvMEukGLy7

With Ethereum users and builders are sovereign and able to determine their own economic destinies.

This is important in an age of declining trust in institutions where many people don‚Äôt have access to stable systems of property rights or economic opportunity.

Ethereum is a global public good that is open, borderless, neutral, transparent, and censorship-resistant.

Ethereum provides a system of property rights, rules, and economic opportunity for anyone in the world with an internet connection. https://t.co/Oab6SlJD79

ETH 2.0 is finally here and will transform Ethereum as we know it.

But what is the philosophy underpinning ETH 2.0? And what is Ethereum building towards?

It all starts with the idea that Ethereum is the foundation of a social contract for the global economy.

This is very cool. New tokens distributed to labor instead of just capital.

Token holders will need to be active or assume risk, and protocols will need to adequately reward their stakeholders who provide value.

The more protocols can align the interest between different stakeholders groups the better.

Meanwhile there are plenty of stakeholders in these protocols that create but don‚Äôt receive any value.

The status quo is inadequate, and the further dealing with this inadequacy is kicked down the road, the harder it will be to deal with.

What we have right now is just property owners extracting rent without providing any value.

This is the blue pill... https://t.co/olvcb1tssE

This is worse than legacy financial institutions.

At least equity holders in legacy financial institutions are in a position of first-loss.

Now that protocols hold capital there needs to be more thought given to their capital structure. 

Right now it‚Äôs all amorphous.

Take Harvest (FARM) for example.

FARM holders currently extract 30% of the protocols fees as profit.

And for what?

Depositors just lost $24 million and token holders aren‚Äôt assuming any of that loss?

But even so voting isn‚Äôt a requirement to receive any fees, 
so voter participation is extremely low. 

Most token holders don‚Äôt do anything.

At the opposite end of the spectrum are tokens that simply extract fees from owning the property everyone uses.

They need not assume any of the systems‚Äô risk. 

In many cases they just vote on proposals that protocol politicians create, who so far are just unpaid labor.

Projects like Maker are at the more ideal end of the spectrum.

MKR holders backstop the entire MakerDAO system.

For assuming this risk they are rewarded with the systems‚Äô income.

This risk also incentivizes MKR holders to be active managing the protocol‚Äôs risk.

The idea that token holders can passively extract rent without providing equal value to a protocol is unsustainable.

In the long-run, token holders will likely need to be active network participants or assume some of the risk of the system to be viable.

How then can DeFi protocols capture value if it appears as if nothing is defensible?

I believe there are five primary sources of sustainable competitive advantage:

- Community
- Integrations
- Protocol Resources
- Security
- Brand / UX

But when code is open source and capital can move freely on the internet, traditional sources of competitive advantage lose their relevance.

Even liquidity can be forked in this world.

This is why building a moat in DeFi is hard.

Balance sheet monetization as a business model is not new. 

It‚Äôs how financial institutions such as banks have generated cash flow for millennia.

Users provide their capital to protocols in exchange for value flows that may be intrinsic (like native token rewards) or extrinsic (like stablecoins).

How much value protocols create for stakeholders is determined by how effectively protocols can monetize their balance sheets. https://t.co/CaBkP0pH5J

Value creation in DeFi all starts with a balance sheet.

DeFi protocols are coordination mechanisms that define rules and provide incentives in order to facilitate financial activity.

This summer it was easy to ignore longer-term questions of sustainability and competitive advantage when all DeFi asset prices were rising.

But now that the market has cooled down, more level heads may now prevail and position for the next stage of DeFi.

Smart stablecoins like yUSD are an exciting addition to DeFi and if they can overcome their challenges today, they could have a bright future.

This and much more in our latest Q3 report on stablecoins.

https://t.co/O7AFoiV7Nn

Not only would increased liquidity allow users to avoid the complexities and fees involved in moving in and out of smart stablecoins today, but they would also allow larger users to move in and out of them with less slippage.
Sufficient liquidity for these yield aware tokens like yUSD would make them significantly more accessible and useful.

As we‚Äôve seen with Black Thursday this would be a nightmare in a high fee, high congestion environment.

Luckily however this risk is slowly being mitigated by the development of yield aware stablecoin optimized AMM protocols like SnowSwap, CreamY, and Curve (new pool).

Further challenging yUSD from a risk perspective is liquidity. 

Currently, there‚Äôs no great way to get in or out of yUSD besides interacting with Yearn‚Äôs yCRV vault. 

To ultimately get to or from the underlying stablecoins it takes multiple steps and transactions.

This peg risk may be addressed in the future by allocating the underlying stablecoins elsewhere to protocols that backstop against this risk, or don‚Äôt introduce it altogether, but for now it‚Äôs there.

Other ideas for how to insure against this would also be welcomed.

yUSD is an incredible product, but it‚Äôs also one of the riskiest stablecoins available on Ethereum.

In addition to compounded smart contract risk, yUSD‚Äôs risk of peg loss is the sum risk of all its underlying stablecoins losing their peg, combined.

Protocols are institutions just as much as they are code.

This is one of many ways in which community matters.

When you find a protocol, ask yourself, if you had to entrust a large portion of your funds to a given protocol how long would you be comfortable doing so?

The only way protocols will have the privilege to store and manage significant portions of the world‚Äôs wealth will be if they‚Äôre managed carefully (like nuclear power plants).

The only way this happens is with sharp, conscientious, thoughtful protocol governors and developers.

In a world where code is law, risk management is essential for DeFi protocols.

Protocol risk is easy to dismiss in hot markets where short-termism and riskiness may bear extremely high rewards, but in the long-run
protocols will ultimately be valued upon institutional trust.

So that‚Äôs how StableCredit works in a nutshell.

But what does it mean for the rest of DeFi and why does it matter for Yearn?
Below is a great visual overview from @finematics of how this works using ETH and LINK as an example. https://t.co/Bpw3s1ohM5
To repay your debt you ‚Äúsell‚Äù the borrowed asset back for StableCredit USD, which you can use to repay your debt and receive your collateral back.

StableCredit USD is like a ‚Äúlending credit‚Äù that allows users to borrow any of the other assets supplied to StableCredit. 

To borrow an asset you ‚Äúsell‚Äù your StableCredit USD for it.

The protocol then calculates a system utilization ratio (what the percentage contribution of the pool you added to the entire ecosystem worth) up to a maximum of 75%, then mints the utilization ratio value of the deposited asset as StableCredit USD.

In the internal StableCredit economy when a user deposits an asset the protocol mints an equivalent amount of StableCredit USD (a new stablecoin) using an oracle to determine price, then supplies the deposited asset and StableCredit USD into a Uniswap pool.
StableCredit allows users to deposit an asset and then receive a credit line that allows them to borrow up to 75% of the collateral they provided.

In a nutshell StableCredit is MakerDAO + Aave + Bancor combined, but with minimal governance and no token ($YFI is not involved). 

The latter two points hint at StableCredit‚Äôs ambition to be truly decentralized infrastructure that requires minimal human interaction to run. https://t.co/zwnrBYVfPS

The high level process is simple. 

Deposit your stablecoins into Swerve to receive SWUSD LP tokens (a receipt for depositing your stablecoins), then stake these tokens in a special Swerve contract (called the liquidity gauge) to earn $SWRV, Swerve‚Äôs governance token.

Farming comes in all shapes and sizes, but one of the most simple examples of how farming works is Swerve -  a new Curve fork.

Swerve offers the opportunity to farm SWRV tokens with stablecoins, allowing farmers to avoid the price risk from farming with volatile cryptoassets.

Unlike ICOs, where investors exchange capital in return for new tokens, yield farming allows investors to acquire tokens by supplying a protocol with capital. 

That capital is then put towards a productive use such as lending or liquidity provisioning.

https://t.co/geSxVIvhYi

Since Compound launched liquidity mining in June, billions of dollars in tokens have been distributed to liquidity providers across various DeFi protocols.

Simply put, yield farming offers investors a novel method for acquiring tokens.

You get it by annualizing the earnings accruing to its treasury.

The inverse of YFI‚Äôs P/E ratio implies that if all YFI holders were to stake they would receive a ~5% annual yield.

YFI currently produces cash at a rate of just over $21 million annualized. 

At its current market cap of $390mm this implies a ~20x P/S ratio, among the lowest in DeFi.

Caveat that YFI currently does not have any significant expenses, so its P/S is effectively its P/E as well. https://t.co/KabrvURBEk

The current economics of YFI's two core Earn (lending optimization) and Vaults (yield farming optimization) products are simple.

YFI charges a 5% gas subsidization (performance) fee on the capital it's managing as well a 0.5% withdrawal fee if users pull their capital out.

With the launch of v2, would-be yield farmers could now simply deposit their funds into a yVault and have their capital automatically allocated across the most optimal strategies available. 

This significantly reduced users' brain damage and gas costs.

The takeaway?

There‚Äôs no single ‚Äúbest‚Äù market cap metric. May not ever be.

How to ‚Äúweight‚Äù the importance of circ vs FD market cap depends on the project.

For example, if 100% of new tokens coming into circulation (i.e no team or investor tokens vesting, project treasury spending, etc), are distributed to token holders who actively participate in the network, then you need not worry about future dilution as an active token holder.

Circulating market cap has many flaws and can be gamed by projects issuing a low circ supply, but fully diluted (FD) market cap isn‚Äôt perfect either.

FD market cap‚Äôs most critical flaw is that it fails to consider how new tokens come into circulation.

Despite not being live, the market could be pricing RUNE at a premium considering THORChain plans to offer a relatively differentiated product in a high-growth sector. 

With a token model that can grow alongside the network, THORChain is well-worth monitoring. https://t.co/XpCrz32o97

THORChain is young and unproven, but it boasts an active community and a hyper-growth incentive model that has contributed to its being priced comparably to other AMMs like Bancor, and alternative interoperability solutions like Ren.

With some clever token economic design the relationship between validators and LPs means the value of RUNE staked and bonded on the network must be at least three times the value of external assets held in liquidity pools (since each pool is 50% RUNE). https://t.co/337SZrAoo2

RUNE doubles as both the base pair for each asset supported by the exchange, and the asset THORNodes bond as collateral to control and secure the flow of assets into and out of liquidity pools. 

RUNE‚Äôs dual utility plays a central role in THORChain‚Äôs economic model.

But Kava‚Äôs more ambitious product vision (like more synthetic assets), interoperability with the Cosmos ecosystem, and creative monetary policy make it an interesting project to watch.

Clearly Kava is prioritizing growth in its early years over value capture. 

Which makes sense given how the previous decades‚Äô traditional tech companies scaled. https://t.co/rRObwEnWNm

Kava‚Äôs interest income is a deflationary force that burns KAVA as interest is paid, but it competes with the inflationary force of inflation rewards distributed to Kava stakers and Kava liquidity providers (new liquidity mining program).

In addition to receiving the economics of the Kava credit system and governance over it, Kava also secures the Kava blockchain, with stakers receiving inflation and fees generated by the Kava blockchain.

The latter point is important because it impacts KAVA‚Äôs economics.

Next $KAVA.

Strong settlement assurances are a necessity for public blockchains as they need to guarantee payments between untrusting and potentially unknown parties. 

These settlement assurances are at the core of what allows public blockchains to scale globally.

https://t.co/B0RvSwjKL3
The purpose of these systems is to fully guarantee payments so that they cannot be repudiated, reversed, or charged back without agreement of the recipient, and they‚Äôre meant to settle immediately.
Instead of comparing public blockchains to card networks like Visa, it would be much better to compare them to large settlement systems like Fedwire, which they more closely resemble.

The arguments are a product of misconceptions around what kinds of payment systems public blockchains are.

And it causes people to draw premature conclusions about public blockchains as payment systems.

The typical argument goes, ‚Äúyou can‚Äôt buy a cup of coffee with Bitcoin‚Äù and ‚Äúcryptocurrencies are too volatile to serve as a medium of exchange.‚Äù 

Both premises aren‚Äôt entirely inaccurate, but the conclusion is.

Bitcoin and Ethereum are on pace to settle a combined $1.3 trillion - their most ever.

Many people think public blockchains have failed as payment systems.

This is just wrong.

In my latest piece I explore the art of DeFi valuation and show how investors' can think about and justify @compoundfinance's valuation in the abscence of traditional methods.

https://t.co/NUcFrl0ZQ1

Some examples on the qualitative side include product-market fit, team, community, and token economics. 

Some examples on the quantitative side include earnings, volumes, users, and various use case specific KPIs - what's important here is growth, not just absolute values.

So then how can we think about DeFi tokens' value? 

To help determine value one can look to a combination of qualitative and quantitative measures.

This should be expected for projects as early as DeFi projects are. 

The overwhelming majority of the value these projects will create is far into the future, which is inherently uncertain. 

But it goes to show how useless relative valuations may be at this stage.

When you consider all these issues combined with the fact that so many of these projects generate such little earnings that the multiples are absurd, it makes it hard to draw any takeaways from the multiples other than that all these projects are extremely overvalued.

The below table provides an excellent overview we can use to highlight issues comparing earnings multiples. (h/t @JulienThevenard)

Some issues include:

- Earnings extrapolating the present
- Different value accrual mechanisms
- Different target markets
- Evolving tokeneconomics https://t.co/gPDHP6XVSU

That we can use relative valuation at this stage is uniquely possible in DeFi given that tokens begin trading publicly virtually from inception.

However, this unique opportunity to attempt valuing DeFi tokens at this stage poses challenges.

Relative valuation is currently the primary method for framing DeFi tokens‚Äô value because fundamental valuation is unreliable for DeFi tokens at this stage.

DeFi tokens are like early stage startups and have too much uncertainty over their future cash flows to build a model off.

The primary method for framing DeFi tokens‚Äô value is Comps - a relative valuation method.

The way this is typically done is by dividing a token‚Äôs market cap by its earnings to arrive at an earnings multiple and comparing that multiple across projects.

The three most common methods used to frame discussions about these tokens‚Äô value are: 

- Discounted Cash Flow (DCF)
- Comparable Company Analysis (Comps) 
- Precedent Transactions (Precedents) https://t.co/1DsVEreSww

Many DeFi tokens produce income through some value extraction mechanism at the protocol level. 

We can frame discussions about these tokens' worth using traditional valuation methods.

However, it's important to remember that for now valuing DeFi tokens is an art.

However, to the degree these estimates are generally accurate, they do provide interesting insights into how investors may behave.
 
https://t.co/VLrt4xYly0

Neither realized cap nor its derivative estimated cost basis are perfect, and there‚Äôs no guarantee that a cryptoassets‚Äô investor base will behave a particular way depending on its estimated cost basis.

BitcoinSV (BSV) has the highest aggregate profit; however, BSV‚Äôs estimated cost basis has likely benefited from a lot of unclaimed coins post-BCH fork.
 
This lowers BSV‚Äôs estimated cost basis substantially considering the value of those unclaimed coins is effectively $0. https://t.co/RHefAazTMA
In these tables we see the best and worse ‚Äúaggregate P&Ls‚Äù for the cryptoassets we calculate realized cap for. https://t.co/aKosjIL9HD

The insights provided by estimated cost basis can provide an interesting view into potential investor behavior.
 
Using estimated cost basis observers can easily see at what price does a cryptoasset, in aggregate, break-even. https://t.co/vD1FHQBk39
Although every trade is not settled on-chain, given that the majority of on-chain activity is related to trading, realized capitalization is a good estimate for aggregate cost basis.

Realized cap was introduced by @coinmetrics in 2018, and is calculated by valuing each unit of supply at the price it last moved on-chain.
 
Realized cap can be thought of as an estimation of the aggregate cost basis of a cryptoasset.
 
https://t.co/qkdiioImQx

Cost basis refers to the original price that an asset was acquired.
 
Estimated cost basis is calculated by dividing a cryptoassets realized capitalization (realized cap) by its current supply.
 
The metric is meant to present realized cap in a more familiar, ‚Äúper coin‚Äù format.

When Bitcoin rocketed to ~$20,000 in 2017 it became front page news.
 
However, despite the hype, not much Bitcoin actually traded near $20,000.
 
Nor has much traded above even half of that.

In fact, the estimated cost basis for the Bitcoin network is just under $6,000.

In my latest pro piece I explain how arbitrageurs take advantage of this opportunity, and lay out the path for ETHE premiums to fall. 

TL;DR - the ETHE premium will likely fall significantly by end of summer.

https://t.co/c06wG3mNOz

As previously stated these premiums create significant arbitrage opportunities for accredited investors that can create new shares in the primary market. 

But why do the premiums remain so high?
The premiums not only cause secondary market investors to buy ETH exposure at absurd prices, but also exposes them to excess volatility given the fluctuating premiums. https://t.co/Iu1H8FIYNE

The ETHE premium has gotten so high that investors are now paying a 750%+ premium for exposure to ETH. 

What this means is that secondary market investors are buying ETHE's underlying ETH at an implied price of $2,095.  

This is 46% above ETH's ATH! https://t.co/CDl7280jSC

Since no new shares are being created, no new cryptocurrency is actually going into the trust, creating a premium to the underlying.

This can create a significant arbitrage opportunity for accredited investors who can create new shares in the primary market.
When there are a lot of buyers and few sellers, investors in the secondary market can push the price of the shares well above the value of the underlying cryptocurrencies.

Initial ETHE shares are only available to accredited investors and can be created either using cash or cryptocurrency ("in-kind").

A ‚ÄúRule 144 exemption‚Äù allows these initial investors to sell shares to the public on secondary markets after a 12-month holding period.

The peculiar structure of Grayscale's trust products have also likely caused many retail investors to misunderstand how much additional risk they're exposing themselves to.

Let's use Grayscale's Ethereum trust (ETHE) as an example.

Grayscale buys way less #Bitcoin than many would think.

Factoring in "in-kind" purchases, Grayscale has only bought 31% of all new bitcoins mined since the halving, far less than the 150%+ many have reported.

This is just one of many misconceptions about Grayscale's trusts.

In short, Ethereum is being used more than ever, and in just two years, Ethereum has evolved from a blank canvas to an agglomeration of novel forms of value and use cases.

Furthermore, the decreased inflation rate is critical in solidifying ETH‚Äôs perception as a scarce asset - an issue that has drawn criticism from the Bitcoin community.

In fact, with EIP 1559 and PoS, higher fees could lead to ETH's net issuance potentially going negative.

Fees are important for a handful of reasons. 

For one, higher fees point towards more sustainability, allowing a blockchain to rely less on new coin issuance for security over time. https://t.co/gh0wIkEpQk

The great part about Ethereum‚Äôs programmability is that it allows Ethereum to quickly adapt and find product-market fit. 

The successes of these experiments have directly translated into increased usage of the Ethereum blockchain, which has also put upward pressure on fees. https://t.co/IWzFONosOU

Still Ethereum‚Äôs increased non-ETH usage is worthy of deeper discussion in its own right, regardless of its long-term implications on ETH‚Äôs monetary premium.

In this respect, it is safe to say that Ethereum‚Äôs increased usage is a positive for the foreseeable future.

Furthermore, ETH's use in DeFi helps to solidify its position as Ethereum‚Äôs primary store of value.

ETH is and will always be the most trust-minimized asset available on Ethereum, and it is for this reason that ETH is the reserve asset for Ethereum financial system (DeFi). https://t.co/VBAouirpE3

As covered previously, ETH's decreasing role as a MoE may not be positive for ETH, at least in the long-term.

The question of how treasury decisions are made is a question of governance, and humans have been struggling with questions of governance for thousands of years.

Treasuries may bring unintended consequences üëá
https://t.co/Y8FcqPqOG0

These questions may not be as critical when a community is small and the stakes are low like it is for projects with existing treasury systems. 

However, when you scale it up to tens of billions of dollars and a large global community decisions become a lot more contentious.

However, all this is not as simple as allocating a portion of Bitcoin‚Äôs block rewards to a treasury and spending it when needed. 

There needs to be a mechanism to decide upon what to fund.

But perhaps most important of all, Bitcoin could fund itself into perpetuity and bootstrap the Bitcoin native economy without reliance on outside entities. 

The ultimate form of blockchain sovereignty is complete and unadulterated autonomy.

With such funding Bitcoin could employ an army of builders to develop its protocol, attracting both missionaries and mercenaries.

Furthermore, Bitcoin could fund many projects that may not easily be productized at a for profit company.
If Bitcoin had Dash‚Äôs funding reward system, Bitcoin could‚Äôve spent a cumulative potential $1.6 billion on its ecosystem, and $500 million in 2019. https://t.co/MOjaU8AkHO

If Bitcoin had Decred‚Äôs treasury system, and ran a similar budget, it would currently have a $9 billion treasury. 

At its peak in 2017, Bitcoin‚Äôs treasury would‚Äôve been worth more than $25 billion. https://t.co/D3Nn2NLLjz

In 2019 Bitcoin paid miners over $5.2 billion for securing its network.

If Bitcoin were a country this amount would place it 41st in annual defense spending.

But what if Bitcoin's block reward allocation was different?

What if Bitcoin reserved a portion for a treasury?
