In 2017 and 2018, cryptocurrency went mainstream.

In 2020 and 2021, cryptocurrency may finally make an impact.

Long-term trends in money, finance, geopolitics, and governance have accelerated in short fashion, accelerating the timeline for cryptocurrency and decentralized technologies along with them. 

Whether we‚Äôre ready or not, cryptocurrencies may be defined in the coming quarters.

As the saying goes, there are decades where nothing happens; and there are weeks where decades happen.

Although we are in the early innings of the coronavirus pandemic, the events of the past few weeks have been breathtaking.

While Bitcoin‚Äôs correlations with the broader markets have been disappointing for some given the price direction, the phenomena marks perhaps the first time Bitcoin has responded to the broader macroeconomic environment.

This is a key milestone along Bitcoin's adoption curve.

Furthermore, according to CoinMetrics data, most the selling came from younger UXTOs, indicating that the majority of the selling was driven by short-term speculators, rather than long-term holders who remain convicted in the face of recent volatility. https://t.co/KMhusRht1t
The silver lining of Bitcoin‚Äôs Black Thursday is that it flushed nearly all the leverage out the system, leading to more healthy investment and mining markets.

The near-term outlook for Bitcoin is as uncertain as it's ever been.

However, Bitcoin may also be the best positioned it's ever been for a rally.

All the above action was great for exchanges. 

The spike in volatility led to some of the highest Bitcoin trading volumes ever in both spot and derivatives markets. https://t.co/UdQhvQE0rX
The hash rate crash caused Bitcoin‚Äôs daily average block times to spike over 15 minutes per block, sparking Bitcoin‚Äôs 2nd largest downward adjustment ever. https://t.co/LlSEOysA7H

The turmoil was felt throughout the mining economy as well which experienced its own deleveraging event. 

With mining revenue halved overnight and the prospects of a Bitcoin halving rally uncertain, many miners found themselves overleveraged, uncompetitive, and mining at a loss. https://t.co/aRQ6Nr90w5

The sell-off was so violent that cryptocurrency market structure broke due to a cascade of large liquidations on derivatives exchanges. 

On BitMEX alone, a total of $1.6 billion of leveraged long positions were liquidated, wiping out nearly all the leverage in the market.

The liquidity crisis was so severe that Bitcoin experienced one of it‚Äôs worst single day declines ever. 

In what will now be remembered as Black Thursday, on March 12, Bitcoin plummeted as much as 50% to its lowest point on the day. https://t.co/GJ2lcsLCpe

However, Bitcoin‚Äôs fate soon changed as fears of COVID-19 began impacting financial markets globally.

The long hailed, albeit weak idea that Bitcoin would remain uncorrelated in a time of crisis was shattered. 

Bitcoin‚Äôs correlation with the S&P 500 rocketed to all-time highs. https://t.co/zz0iAzofei

With clear skies ahead, halving abound, and momentum from an 84% rise in 2019, Bitcoin started the year on a tear. 

In the first 45 days of 2020 Bitcoin rose more than 45%, reaching a high of $10,362.

Q1 2020 was one of the most eventful quarters in the history of cryptocurrency. 

Everything we thought would happen in 2020 collided with the highly improbable and extremely impactful exogenous shock of the coronavirus.

The Bitcoin blockchain will keep trucking along producing blocks every 10 minutes -  a beacon of stability in unstable times.

The set of Bitcoin miners consists of numerous independent entities with their own cost structures and balance sheets.

Miners don‚Äôt rise and fall as one, they rise and fall as individuals. Mining is a competition, and the least competitive miners simply just lose and exit.

People have been calling for ‚Äúmining death spirals‚Äù for 9 years now, yet the game theory underpinning why this is not the case is simple.

If the price of BTC falls, marginal miners go offline, and Bitcoin readjusts its mining difficulty to ensure stable block times.
The adjustment will provide much needed relief to remaining miners, who have taken much longer to mine blocks following the hash rate drop off. https://t.co/KIwv4dpoeK

Anyone who‚Äôs familiar with Bitcoiners, knows the 21 million hard cap is non-negotiable. This is why despite all the clones, there is only one digital gold.

Many cryptocurrencies promise absolute scarcity, but no project‚Äôs assurance of such scarcity comes close to Bitcoin‚Äôs.

In order to break Bitcoin‚Äôs assurance, you need to convince a global ecosystem of independent and diverse participants to alter Bitcoin‚Äôs social contract.

However, the most important reason to hold Bitcoin is it‚Äôs credible assurance of absolute scarcity. 

There is no known total amount of gold in the world, but there will only ever be 21 million bitcoins. 

Bitcoin is awarded this property because of it‚Äôs governance.

But what‚Äôs the purpose of Bitcoin, when gold has a 5,000 year track record, and an order(s) of magnitude more liquidity?

There are many reasons to hold Bitcoin over gold including transferability, availability, ease of storage, seizure-resistance, and censorship-resistance.

5/ None of this should be a shock to crypto analysts and investors.

4/ Beyond legal rights, exchange tokens also do not offer holders many protocol rights ‚Äì the right to perform some action in a protocol.

3/ As a handful of analysts have astutely pointed out, exchange tokens are not like equity because they do not legally confer any rights onto holders. 

Tokens represent an informal claim on cash flow. 

Furthermore, no one really knows where tokens sit in the capital structure.

2/ At first glance the theory made sense. Exchange tokens offer what seems like a claim on cash flow.

This excited many investors as they could utilize familiar tools to value these tokens.

Exchange tokens thus became the first cryptoassets with a clear valuation methodology.

Exchange tokens are not equity.

Exchange tokens are far more enigmatic than we would like them to be.
